page.title: Reflect before you start
page.contents:
This lesson is called Acceleration.  It will cover:

  • Developing an intuitive idea of the meaning of acceleration
  • Motion with constant acceleration
  • Strategies for analyzing motion with non-constant acceleration
  • The vector nature of acceleration

Before you start to look at any complicated content, whether it is a textbook, a set of video lectures, a web page, whatever, it is a good idea to prepare to learn by doing a bit of reflection.  To develop the habit it is good to write some reflections.  In the space below write three things (sentences, point form, whatever you want) about what you are about to learn.  Here are some things you might write about below:

  • List things that you think you might learn about in the lesson (in more detail than was given in the list above).
  • List things that you already know about the topics of this lesson.
  • List things that you have heard about these topics, but don't understand.

answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: Main page - choose lesson part here
page.contents:
You do not have to finish the lesson all in one sitting.  You may reattempt it if you are not satisfied with how you did.  Here is a "map" of the lesson.  This is partly because moodle has a tendency (which I haven't figured out) to skip the Reflective Writing parts of these lessons.  This map will help you see if you have missed any and find your way to where they should be.

Choose one of the following lesson parts.  When you have finished that part of the lesson you will be brought back to this page.  When you have finished all parts of the lesson click the "OK, I'm done" button to end the lesson.

page.title: Choose correct acceleration vectors for motion diagram
page.contents:
Consider this motion diagram, which is missing its acceleration vectors.

Which of the following is the correct set of acceleration vectors for this motion diagram?

answer.response: Yes.

No.  For example, notice that the first few points are equal distances apart.  The object is moving at a constant velocity for the first little while.  What does that tell you about the acceleration during that time?

No.  For example, notice that the first few points are equal distances apart.  The object is moving at a constant velocity for the first little while.  What does that tell you about the acceleration during that time?

No.  Notice that for the  few points before the object stops and reverses direction the points are getting closer together.  So it is slowing down during that time.  What does this tell you about the direction of the acceleration during that time?

page.title: Choose ax vs. t
page.contents: Below is a vx vs. t graph.  Which of the options below is the most correct ax vs. t graph?

answer.response: Yes.
No.  For example, notice that for the first while the vx vs. t graph has a negative slope.  What does this tell you?
No.  For example, notice that for the first while the vx vs. t graph has a negative slope.  What does this tell you?
No.  You've chosen a graph that looks just like the vx vs. t graph.  ax is not the same as vx.  You can find ax from the slope of the vx vs. t graph...

page.title: Which mass falls faster?
page.contents:
I have two metal masses - one 100 g and one 500 g.  If I drop them both at the same time from the same height, which will hit the ground first?

(Note: be sure to read the feedback because the lesson will take you onwards to the next part of the lesson whether your prediction was correct or incorrect.)

answer.answer_text: They will hit at the same time.
answer.response: Yes, as you are about to see in the next video that is what happens.
No. Watch the video to see what actually happens.
No. Watch the video to see what actually happens.

page.title: which is the correct set of knowns? - 2
page.contents:
We define east as positive.  A car starts at the origin going east at 30 m/s.  It slows down at a rate of 5 m/s2 until it comes to rest.

Which of the sets of knowns/unknowns below is consistent with this description?

answer.answer_text: x<sub>i</sub> = 0, x<sub>f</sub> = ?, v<sub>x,i</sub> = 30 m/s, v<sub>x,f</sub> = 0, a<sub>x</sub> = -5 m/s<sup>2</sup>, Delta t = ?
answer.response: Yes.

answer.answer_text: x<sub>i</sub> = 0, x<sub>f</sub> = ?, v<sub>x,i</sub> = 30 m/s, v<sub>x,f</sub> = 0, a<sub>x</sub> = 5 m/s<sup>2</sup>, Delta t = ?
answer.response: No. Think about which way the acceleration vector points.

answer.answer_text: x<sub>i</sub> = 0, x<sub>f</sub> = ?, v<sub>x,i</sub> = 30 m/s, v<sub>x,f</sub> = 0, a<sub>x</sub> = ?, Delta t = ?
answer.response: No, we have been told the acceleration. Remember that objects that are slowing down are accelerating.

answer.answer_text: x<sub>i</sub> = ?, x<sub>f</sub> = ?, v<sub>x,i</sub> = 30 m/s, v<sub>x,f</sub> = 0, a<sub>x</sub> = 5 m/s<sup>2</sup>, Delta t = ?
answer.response: No, we have been told the initial position (but not by being given a number. Also, think about what direction the acceleration points.

page.title: match v vs. t to correct a vs. t
page.contents: Which of the acceleration vs. time graphs below (A, B, C or D) is the best match for the velocity vs. time graph shown?

answer.response: Yes, the a vs. t graph at every time is the slope of the v. vs. t graph at that time.
No. For example, at the start the value of vx is constant for a while. What does this tell you about ax during the first little while?
No. I think you are looking at the area under the vx vs. t graph (which is much harder than what you should be doing). ax is the *slope* of the vx vs. t graph...
No. This one is identical to the v vs. t graph. But the a vs. t graph is determined from the **slope** of the v vs. t graph.

page.title: Reflect on what you have learned
page.contents:
Take out a piece of paper.  Write "PHYS 1104 - Response to Unit 3 Video Lectures" across the top of the paper.  Don't put your name on it; I would rather mark "blind".  Write a big heading saying "First Half".  

Under that heading answer the following questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Question beyond the lecture: Ask a question that goes beyond what was covered in the lectures.  This could be a question about a topic that you think might be related to the lectures, or something that you suspect might be a more advanced topic that the material in these lectures might eventually lead to.  Or it might be something that I mentioned briefly, but didn't go into detail on.  Make your question as specific as you can.

3. List all of the information that should be included in a complete motion diagram.

You will add more to this sheet after one of the other lectures in this unit.  You will take a picture of your written response to the lesson with your phone and submit it to moodle after you have finished the lesson.

page.title: match v vs. t to correct a vs. t -1
page.contents: Which of the acceleration vs. time graphs below (A, B, C or D) is the best match for the velocity vs. time graph shown?

answer.response: Yes, the a vs. t graph is just the slope of the v vs. t graph.
No, that's what the x vs. t graph for this motion might look like. Remember that a vs. t is the slope of v vs. t, not the other way around.

There are a number of misconceptions about acceleration which might cause you to choose this answer. You may have a misconception that a forward acceleration is needed for an object to keep moving forward. Or you may think that smaller velocity implies smaller acceleration. Remember, the acceleration is the **slope** of the v vs. t graph.

There are a number of misconceptions about acceleration which might cause you to choose this answer. You may have a misconception that a forward acceleration is needed for an object to keep moving forward. Or you may think that smaller velocity implies smaller acceleration. Remember, the acceleration is the **slope** of the v vs. t graph.

page.title: Describe the motion
page.contents: Below is a vx vs. t graph for some object.  Which is the best description of this object's motion?

answer.answer_text: The object is speeding up from t = 0 until t = 3 s. It is momentarily at its maximum speed at t = 3 s. It slows down after that.
answer.response: Yes.

answer.answer_text: The object is moving to the right from t = 0 until t = 3 s. It momentarily stops at t = 3 s. It then moves to the left after t = 3 s.
answer.response: No. You are interpreting the graph as if it is an x vs. t graph.

answer.answer_text: The object is slowing down from t = 0 until t = 3 s. It momentarily stops at t = 3 s. It then moves in the opposite direction speeding up after t = 3 s.
answer.response: No. You are interpreting the graph as if it is an x vs. t graph.

answer.answer_text: The object's acceleration is increasing from t = 0 until t = 3 s. It has its maximum acceleration momentarily at t = 3 s. Then its acceleration decreases after t = 3 s.
answer.response: No. You are interpreting the graph as if it was an a_x vs. t graph. In fact, by the slope of this v_x vs. t graph you can tell that the acceleration is *decreasing* from t = 0 to t = 3 s and the magnitude of the acceleration is *increasing* after t = 3 s.

page.title: what is final velocity?
page.contents:
Suppose we know the initial velocity and initial height of this projectile.  If we define impact with the ground as our “final” time, what is the final velocity of the projectile?

Moodle will not let you go on until you have answered this question correctly.  It will give you hints if you give an incorrect answer.

answer.answer_text: We don't know.  We would need to solve for it.
answer.response: Yes.

No.  Certainly after it hits the ground (after a bounce or two) it makes sense that the projectile would be stationary.  But that is not what we mean.  We will be using equations of uniformly accelerated motion to analyze the motion of the projectile.  Those only apply as long as the acceleration is uniform.  But when the projectile hits the ground its acceleration changes.  So our equations can't "see beyond the collision with the ground".

No.  g is an acceleration and we are talking about a velocity.  This answer indicates that you may believe that objects in freefall fall with a constant *speed*.  They do not.  They fall with a constant acceleration.  Also, we are looking for a velocity, which is a vector.  But "g" is a scalar.

page.title: which is the correct set of knowns?
page.contents:
We define east as positive.  A car starts at the origin going east at 30 m/s.  It is slowing down at a constant rate.  It comes to rest after going 200 m.

Which of the sets of knowns/unknowns below is consistent with this description?

answer.answer_text: x<sub>i</sub> = 0, x<sub>f</sub> = 200 m, v<sub>x,i</sub> = 30 m/s, v<sub>x,f</sub> = 0, a<sub>x</sub> = ?, Delta t = ?
answer.response: Yes.

answer.answer_text: x<sub>i</sub> = 0, x<sub>f</sub> = 200 m, v<sub>x,i</sub> = 30 m/s, v<sub>x,f</sub> = 0, a<sub>x</sub> = 0, Delta t = ?
answer.response: No. Remember that objects that are slowing down are accelerating in the physics meaning of the term.

answer.answer_text: x<sub>i</sub> = 0, x<sub>f</sub> = 200 m, v<sub>x,i</sub> = 30 m/s, v<sub>x,f</sub> = ?, a<sub>x</sub> = ?, Delta t = ?
answer.response: No. We know the final velocity, though it isn't given as a number in the question.

answer.answer_text: x<sub>i</sub> = 0, x<sub>f</sub> = 200 m, v<sub>x,i</sub> = 30 m/s, v<sub>x,f</sub> = 0, a<sub>x</sub> = -30 m/s<sup>2</sup>, Delta t = ?
answer.response: No, we have not been given the acceleration. Don't confuse acceleration with velocity.

page.title: Initial velocity and acceleration
page.contents: A search and rescue airplane is flying horizontally at 45 m/s when it drops a package.  What are the velocity and acceleration of the package just after it is dropped using the coordinate system shown on the diagram?

answer.response: Yes.

No.  First of all, after being dropped the package is only under the influence of gravity.  What does that tell you about its acceleration?  Second of all, you may not be understanding what is meant by *just* after the package has been dropped.  No time has elapsed since it was dropped and so there has been no time for its velocity to change.
No.  After being dropped the package is only under the influence of gravity.  What does that tell you about its acceleration?
No.  \( \vec{v}_i \) points left but x is defined as positive to the right.  What does that tell you about the x-component of the velocity?

answer.answer_text: We need to know the x and y distances to the airplane from the origin.
answer.response: No.  We would need that for the initial x- and y-components of *position*.  But they are not relevant at all to knowing the velocity and acceleration.

page.title: match motion diagram to correct acceleration vectors -1
page.contents: Below is a motion diagram without acceleration vectors added.  Which figure (A, B, C or D) shows the correct acceleration vectors for this motion diagram?

answer.response: Yes, the early part of the motion is with constant velocity, then it is slowing down so the acceleration points opposite to the motion.
No. You may be confusing velocity with acceleration. Look back near the beginning of the lecture at what the only three possibilities are for acceleration vectors in one dimension.
No. You may be confusing velocity with acceleration. Look back near the beginning of the lecture at what the only three possibilities are for acceleration vectors in one dimension.

You may have the very common misconception that an object must acceleration to maintain a constant speed. This may be caused by mixing up the idea of acceleration with the idea of how much "effort" it takes to walk at a constant speed. Acceleration and effort are entirely different from each other.

answer.answer_text: None of them. Without axes defined we can't figure out the sign of the acceleration vector.
answer.response: We eventually found that the direction of the acceleration vector for 1D motion only depends on whether the object is speeding up, slowing down, or moving with constant velocity. Have another look at the beginning of this lecture and think about what the answer would have been if we had reversed the sign convention.

page.title: match motion diagram to correct acceleration vectors -2
page.contents: Below is a motion diagram without acceleration vectors added.  Which figure (A, B, C or D) shows the correct acceleration vectors for this motion diagram?

answer.response: Yes, it is speeding up initially (accel. points in direction of motion) then it slows down (accel. points opposite to motion)
No. You may be confusing velocity with acceleration.
No. Remember that in physics terminology an object that is slowing down is accelerating.
No. Remember that in physics terminology an object that is slowing down is accelerating.

answer.answer_text: None of them. Without axes defined we can't figure out the sign of the acceleration vector.
answer.response: We eventually found that the direction of the acceleration vector for 1D motion only depends on whether the object is speeding up, slowing down, or moving with constant velocity. Have another look at the beginning of this lecture and think about what the answer would have been if we had reversed the sign convention.

page.title: Reflect on what you have learned
page.contents:
You should already have a sheet of paper that you wrote some things on after the first half of the lesson.

Under what you wrote for the first half of the lesson write a heading saying "End of Lectures".  

Under that answer these questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Something you have seen before: Identify something from any of the videos on this unit that you have seen before.  If it was presented differently from how you have seen it previously then briefly describe the difference.  It is not acceptable to say that nothing in the videos was something you have seen before.  All knowledge is built on earlier knowledge and there must be something in these videos that was at least somewhat familiar.

3. Explain, in your own words, what each of the following represents: (a) slope of a \( v_x \) vs. \( t \) curve at a point on the curve, (b) slope of a line joining two points on a \( v_x \) vs. \( t \) curve, (c) area under an \( a_x \) vs. \( t \) curve, (d) area under a \( v_x \) vs. \( t \) curve.

You will take a picture of your written response to the lesson with your phone and submit it to moodle after you have finished the lesson.

answer.response: $@NULL@$

page.title: All reflections
page.contents:
This is only here so that if the Lesson navigation failed and you couldn't access one of the Reflective Writing pages you can view their content here.  Most of the time there should be no need for you to visit this page.

----------First Half-----------

Take out a piece of paper.  Write "PHYS 1104 - Response to Unit 3 Video Lectures" across the top of the paper.  Don't put your name on it; I would rather mark "blind".  Write a big heading saying "First Half".  

Under that heading answer the following questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Question beyond the lecture: Ask a question that goes beyond what was covered in the lectures.  This could be a question about a topic that you think might be related to the lectures, or something that you suspect might be a more advanced topic that the material in these lectures might eventually lead to.  Or it might be something that I mentioned briefly, but didn't go into detail on.  Make your question as specific as you can.

3. List all of the information that should be included in a complete motion diagram.

You will add more to this sheet after one of the other lectures in this unit.  You will take a picture of your written response to the lesson with your phone and submit it to moodle after you have finished the lesson.

------------End of Lesson-----------

You should already have a sheet of paper that you wrote some things on after the first half of the lesson.

Under what you wrote for the first half of the lesson write a heading saying "End of Lectures".  

 Under that answer these questions:

1. Point of confusion: Identify something that confused you during the lecture.  If you are still confused by it then try to explain, in reasonable detail, exactly why you are confused.  If you are no longer confused then explain how you resolved your confusion (i.e. what realizations led you to no longer being confused).  Be as specific as you can about the nature of your confusion.  It is not acceptable to simply say that you were not confused by anything.  If you think you were not confused by anything then you are not thinking about the material carefully enough.

2. Something you have seen before: Identify something from any of the videos on this unit that you have seen before.  If it was presented differently from how you have seen it previously then briefly describe the difference.  It is not acceptable to say that nothing in the videos was something you have seen before.  All knowledge is built on earlier knowledge and there must be something in these videos that was at least somewhat familiar.

3. Explain, in your own words, what each of the following represents: (a) slope of a \( v_x \) vs. \( t \) curve at a point on the curve, (b) slope of a line joining two points on a \( v_x \) vs. \( t \) curve, (c) area under an \( a_x \) vs. \( t \) curve, (d) area under a \( v_x \) vs. \( t \) curve.

You will take a picture of your written response to the lesson with your phone and submit it to moodle after you have finished the lesson.

page.title: Direction of acceleration of ball
page.contents:
You throw a ball straight up. After it leaves your hand, as it moves upward it will slow down. A motion diagram for the ball during the upward part of its motion is shown below.

Which way does the ball’s acceleration vector point during this motion?

answer.response: No.  It is *going* up, which means its velocity is up.  But that does not mean its acceleration is up.  Use the rules and/or procedures that I just explained to find the direction of the acceleration.
Yes.
No.  If the acceleration was zero the velocity would not be changing.  But the ball is slowing down, so its velocity is changing.  Therefore the acceleration is not zero.
Vectors cannot be negative (or positive).  There is no such direction as "negative".

page.title: Describe the motion - 2
page.contents: Below is a vx vs. t graph for some object.  Which of the following is the best description of this object's motion?

answer.answer_text: The object speeds up during the whole time shown. Its x-component of acceleration is increasing from t = 0 until t = 3 s and decreasing after t = 3 s.
The object is slowing down from t = 0 until t = 3 s and speeding up after t = 3 s.
answer.response: No. The v_x is getting larger during the whole time shown (v_x is +ve and has a +ve slope). The changes in slope on the graph are telling you about changes in the acceleration.

answer.answer_text: The object's x-component of acceleration is increasing the during whole time shown. It increases at an increasing rate from t = 0 until t = 3 s and it increases at an decreasing rate after t = 3 s.
answer.response: No. The slope is telling you about the acceleration. Notice that the graph is getting steeper early (the x-component of acceleration is increasing) but decreasing later (the x-component of acceleration is decreasing).

answer.answer_text: The object is speeding up from t = 0 until t = 3 s and slowing down after t = 3 s. Around t = 6 s it stops.
answer.response: No you are interpreting the graph as if it was an x vs. t graph.
